TopicTitle: [Possible hardware/thermal problem] Persistent BSODs - I can't play KSP anymore?

Articles.Content:
This has been going on since February. Today, I was going to launch something I assembled in the VAB, so I clicked on the button to take me to the launch pad. But then it froze for a few seconds, and this showed up:

![teg18fe.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/teg18fe.jpg)

(In this particular incident, I had Kerbal Engineer installed, **but the freezes still happen even if there are no mods**)

After I rebooted, CCleaner notified me of a giant MEMORY.DMP file. Was it a "memory leak"? (Also note my lack of a proper graphics card)

![7Dm1rzg.png](http://i.imgur.com/7Dm1rzg.png)

I then removed Kerbal Engineer and tried to play again. **A problem still happened with stock KSP, and for no particular reason.** I successfully launched my rocket to orbit, but as I was switching between map views, it froze. After a few minutes, I didn't want to wait until the inevitable BSOD, so I just turned off the surge protector.

I've read that there is an issue in which the temperature gauges cause memory leaks. But they never appeared, and I turned them off with F10 before I pressed space bar.

I'm sorry, but I don't think I can play KSP anymore if this keeps happening.

edit: Also, my graphics drivers are already up-to-date.

![U9N4MWu.png](http://i.imgur.com/U9N4MWu.png)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-05-14T06:28:22Z" title="05/14/2015 06:28  AM" data-short="9 yr">May 14, 2015</time> by Pipcard**

The watchdog timer failed to break a loop; that indicates a hardware problem.

Basically, KSP crashed, yes... but your system called an interrupt to gain access to the core KSP was running on; and your processor appears not to have responded to said interrupt.

**Are you now, or have you in the past, over-clocked your processor?**

(Memory dump is just a dump; usually if you know what you're doing (and have access to KSP's source) you can use that to diagnose the problem. Of course, the debug logs are generally better.)

I'm not certain of a good stress test here, I suspect the processor is going past the maximum thermal operating point at which the noise factor is low enough for it to keep operating without faults. Since your processor is both a GPU and a CPU in the same package, and both are being stressed when you encounter these errors, it is likely that simply stressing the CPU won't cause issues.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-05-14T02:01:09Z" title="05/14/2015 02:01  AM" data-short="9 yr">May 14, 2015</time> by Fel**

I have never overclocked at all.

just a question: is it because the insides of the computer are dusty? I only got the computer in April 2012.

The dust isn't too much of an issue (it helps to remove it, but putting down a new coating of thermal paste over the top of the processor would help more.)

[http://www.wikihow.com/Apply-Thermal-Paste](https://www.wikihow.com/Apply-Thermal-Paste)

(Don't sand it.)

If you aren't overclocking, then it is possible that the heatsink used is not the proper grade for the processor (I'm not sure how to check this), but some companies may elect to use a cheaper sub-standard sink and market their computers as "business machines." That might explain why you're developing problems after only 3 years. If applying the thermal paste doesn't work, you likely would want to either try individual CPU / GPU stress tests to confirm and possibly bring it in to see if the Heatsink is the right model.

\*Of course, the internet has all kinds of insanity to "fix" this; if you really want to try random things; it sounds like thermal issues to me though.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-05-14T03:54:53Z" title="05/14/2015 03:54  AM" data-short="9 yr">May 14, 2015</time> by Fel**

Oh no, I have *always* been worried about this "thermal paste" ever since I first read about it. What if I accidentally squeeze too much? What if I put it back together and it turns out to be [**bricked**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brick_%28electronics%29)? This is also why I have never built my own PC either.

([This is where I bought the computer from.](http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16883229310))

You say it's dusty, how dusty?, if the fan is caked with dust and cannot turn fast enough you will have heating issues.

The catalyst driver should show you how hot your Apu is getting.

There's a fair amount of dust on the fans, could that be it?

Could that also be the reason why my computer can't wake up from hibernation on some occasions?

**Edited <time datetime="2015-05-15T21:05:32Z" title="05/15/2015 09:05  PM" data-short="9 yr">May 15, 2015</time> by Pipcard**

> 
> There's a fair amount of dust on the fans, could that be it?

Clogged fans can easily cause overheating (and, potentially, fatal hardware damage). Addressing that before it does serious damage is fairly easy and cheap to do. See [eg here](http://www.techradar.com/news/computing/how-to-clean-your-pc-of-dust-and-dirt-936244).
